aurelienribon.slidinglayout
Class SLTransition

java.lang.Object
  aurelienribon.slidinglayout.SLTransition

public class SLTransition
extends java.lang.Object

A transition consists of one or more keyframes (ie. configurations). The engine will move the children of the panel from the current configuration to the first keyframe, and so on.

If a component is present on a keyframe but absent from the current configuration, it will be considered to be a new component. If you don't specify anything, it will appear right at its target place, which may not be very nice. Instead, you can set its starting side, the side from where it should be brought into view to its target place. It will then slide from this side to its target place.

Similarly, if a component is present in the current configuration but absent from the next keyframe, it will be considered to be an old component. You can slide it out of the screen gracefully by specifying its ending side.

Author:
Aurelien Ribon | http://www.aurelienribon.com/
See Also:
SLConfig, SLKeyframe

push

public SLTransition push(SLKeyframe kf)
Adds a new keyframe to the transition.

play

public boolean play()
Attempts to start the transition. Returns true if everything went right. If another transition was already running, nothing happens and the method returns false;
